content: Singaporean politician and historian (1931–1983) **Wong Lin Ken** ([Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language): 黄麟根; 1931 – 16 February 1983) was a Singaporean politician and historian. He served as the first [Ambassador of Singapore to the United States](/wiki/List_of_ambassadors_of_Singapore_to_the_United_States). A member of the [People's Action Party](/wiki/People%27s_Action_Party) (PAP), Wong also served as the [Minister for Home Affairs](/wiki/Minister_for_Home_Affairs_(Singapore)) from 1970 to 1972 and the Member of Parliament (MP) representing [Alexandra Constituency](/wiki/Alexandra_Constituency) from 1968 to 1976. ## Early life Wong was born in 1931 in [Penang](/wiki/Penang), which was then a part of the [Straits Settlements](/wiki/Straits_Settlements). He attended St. George's Boys School in [Balik Pulau](/wiki/Balik_Pulau) and [Penang Free School](/wiki/Penang_Free_School). He later won a Government Bursary to study at the [University of Malaya](/wiki/University_of_Malaya) and a [Queen's Scholar](/wiki/Queen%27s_Scholar_(British_Malaya_and_Singapore)) to study at the [University of London](/wiki/University_of_London). In 1959, he got a doctorate in history. In 1953, Wong went on an expedition trip led by G. de G. Sieveking, including [Emily Sadka](/wiki/Emily_Sadka), where they found masonry in Malay fortifications and the remains of an ancient Chinese trading ship. ## Academic career Wong worked as a senior lecturer in history at the [University of Singapore](/wiki/University_of_Singapore) and was also the chairman of the Adult Education Board. He briefly left the university from 1967 to 1968 when he was appointed as the [Ambassador of Singapore to the United States](/wiki/List_of_ambassadors_of_Singapore_to_the_United_States) and returned to the university after the stint. ## Political career Wong made his political debut in 1964 at the [1964 Malaysian general election](/wiki/1964_Malaysian_general_election) where he contested for Bukit Bintang as a [People's Action Party](/wiki/People%27s_Action_Party) (PAP) candidate against Tan Toh Hong of [Alliance Party](/wiki/Alliance_Party_(Malaysia)), [Ishak Muhamad](/wiki/Ishak_Muhamad) of [Socialist Front](/wiki/Malayan_Peoples%27_Socialist_Front), and Abdul Aziz Ismail of [Malaysian Islamic Party](/wiki/Malaysian_Islamic_Party). He lost with 31.12% of the vote. In 1967, Wong was appointed the first [Ambassador of Singapore to the United States](/wiki/List_of_ambassadors_of_Singapore_to_the_United_States) which ended in 1968. During the [1968 general election](/wiki/1968_Singaporean_general_election), Wong contested for Member of Parliament (MP) of [Alexandra Constituency](/wiki/Alexandra_Constituency) and was elected unopposed. In 1970, Wong was appointed the [Minister for Home Affairs](/wiki/Minister_for_Home_Affairs_(Singapore)) (MHA). In 1971, Wong announced the formation of the [Central Narcotics Bureau](/wiki/Central_Narcotics_Bureau), a department under the MHA, to combat [drug trafficking and distribution](/wiki/Illegal_drug_trade) and is responsible for coordinating all matters pertaining to drug eradication in Singapore. In the [1972 general election](/wiki/1972_Singaporean_general_election), Wong contested for MP of Alexandra Constituency again, against Wong Kui Yu from [Workers' Party](/wiki/Workers%27_Party_(Singapore)) and S. A. Hamid from [United National Front](/wiki/United_National_Front_(Singapore)). He was elected with 77.52% of the vote. Wong was also the director of the External Affairs Bureau of the [People's Action Party](/wiki/People%27s_Action_Party). He was part of a five-man delegation led by [Minister for Interior and Defense](/wiki/Ministry_of_Interior_and_Defence) [Goh Keng Swee](/wiki/Goh_Keng_Swee) that attended the 1966 [U.N. General Assembly](/wiki/U.N._General_Assembly). ## Death On 16 February 1983, Wong [committed suicide by hanging](/wiki/Suicide_by_hanging) using a nylon cord in his bathroom after having heard a loud noise from his neighbour's house. According to his wife, Lilli Wong, and his psychiatrist, Ho Eng Siong, he had been suffering from depression and entered a panicked reaction after the sudden loud noise. He was cremated at [Mount Vernon Columbarium](/wiki/Mount_Vernon_Columbarium) and was survived by his wife and three children.
